1.text: The code in WorkbenchActionBuilder.propertyChange assumes that the new value in the change event is (a) always non-null, and (b) always of the expected type.

2.text: While both condition may hold in the current world, this assumption might lead to breakage in the future.

3.text: The problem will occur if the property store is changed by some other party.

4.text: In particular, if the other party uses setToDefault() instead of setValue, the new value will either be null or a string (regardless of its usual type).

6.text: This behavior is true of the older JFace  preference store as well as the newer Core preferences.)

7.text: General rule: listeners for property change events should be written in an unassuming manner.
